content: The Uruguay Round of Multilateral Trade Negotiations, initiated in 1986 under GATT, concluded in 1994 with the signing of the WTO Agreement. This agreement requires countries to accept all negotiated trade agreements. It includes long-standing GATT obligations and new agreements, such as rules on tariffs, quotas, subsidies, and embargoes. The Uruguay Round package expands on trade obligations, including the Dispute Settlement Understanding (DSU) for resolving disputes between WTO Members. Dispute settlement involves consultations, panels, and possible appeals, with non-compliance leading to compensation or retaliatory measures. The Uruguay Round Agreement Act (URAA) implemented WTO agreements in the United States, addressing legal effects and prohibiting private remedies for alleged violations. It also requires the USTR to update Congress on disputes challenging U.S. laws. The URAA implements WTO agreements in the US, requires USTR to update Congress on disputes challenging US laws, and mandates agencies to implement WTO decisions. The URAA approves and implements WTO agreements in the US, providing new authorities and repealing outdated provisions. It states that domestic law supersedes any conflicting WTO provisions and requires specific congressional or administrative action to implement WTO decisions challenged in the US. Section 102(a)(1) of the URAA emphasizes that U.S. law takes precedence over any conflicting provisions in the Uruguay Round Agreements. It clarifies that no changes to U.S. law will be made unless specifically outlined in the act, ensuring that necessary adjustments to implement WTO agreements are included in the URAA. Section 102 of the URAA clarifies that U.S. law takes precedence over conflicting provisions in the WTO agreements. Changes to U.S. law necessary for implementing the agreements are included in the URAA, with any unforeseen conflicts to be addressed in subsequent legislation. The approach taken by Congress ensures that necessary changes in federal statutes are specifically enacted, not preempted by international agreements. The U.S. Commerce Department's practice of "zeroing" in antidumping investigations, which assigns a zero value to sales at or above fair market value, has been challenged in WTO disputes. Despite adverse WTO rulings, U.S. courts have upheld the practice as permissible under the antidumping statute.
